prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Science Goal CO10 (PG1302-102)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are designed to detect redshifted CO(1-0) emission from the QSO host. The other three basebands are set up to detect continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.28) of PG 1302-102 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 0.47 Jy km / s. For the adopted line width of 250 km/s (i.e., the average FWHM velocity width for a PG QSO host detected thus far in CO) and a square top CO line profile, a 8 sigma detection corresponds to a rms flux density of 0.24 mJy. Given a velocity resolution of 100 km/s, a per channel rms of 0.24 mJy can be achieved, including calibrations, in 82 minutes. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 5 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Science Goal CO10 (PG0026+129)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are designed to detect redshifted CO(1-0) emission from the QSO host. The other three basebands are set up to detect continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.14) of PG 0026+129 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 7.5 Jy km / s. For the adopted line width of 250 km/s (i.e., the average FWHM velocity width for a PG QSO host detected thus far in CO) and a square top CO line profile, a 11 sigma detection corresponds to a rms flux density of 0.0.71 mJy. Given a velocity resolution of 20 km/s, a per channel rms of 0.71 mJy can be achieved, including calibrations, in 53 minutes. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 15 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.16) of PG 1307+085 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 1.6 Jy km / s. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 15 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.24) of PG 1004+130 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 0.63 Jy km / s. For the adopted line width of 250 km/s (i.e., the average FWHM velocity width for a PG QSO host detected thus far in CO) and a square top CO line profile, a 9.5 sigma detection corresponds to a rms flux density of 0.27 mJy. Given a velocity resolution of 20 km/s, a per channel rms of 0.27 mJy can be achieved, including calibrations, in 71 minutes. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 6 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Science Goal CO10 (PG1435-067)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are designed to detect redshifted CO(1-0) emission from the QSO host. The other three basebands are set up to detect continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A molecular gas mass of 1x10^9 M_sun at the redshift (= 0.13) of PG 1435-067 corresponds to an observed flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 2.4 Jy km / s. For the adopted line width of 250 km/s (i.e., the average FWHM velocity width for a PG QSO host detected thus far in CO) and a square top CO line profile, a 11 sigma detection corresponds to a rms flux density of 0.90 mJy. Given a velocity resolution of 20 km/s, a per channel rms of 0.90 mJy can be achieved, including calibrations, in 43 minutes. If the molecular gas mass is comparable to the faintest QSO hosts in our sample (4x10^8 M_sun), a 15 sigma rms detection can be achieved across the full linewidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the hypothesis that bright UV-excess Palomar-Green (PG) QSOs reside in molecular gas-rich hosts by obtaining CO(1-0) observations of the 5 most luminous, distant PG QSO hosts which were undetected in our z < 0.3 IRAM 30m Telescope survey. Approximately 38% of the hosts were detected, with most detections being of z < 0.12 hosts. Of the more distant, bright QSOs with high stellar mass hosts, only major mergers were detected. We focus here on QSOs with relatively undisturbed hosts; these hosts are ellipticals or late-stage mergers. Their far-IR excesses favor the latter interpretation, thus they may be the tail-end of the ULIRG-to-optical QSO evolution. These observations, combined with our IRAM data, will enable us to assess the star formation properties over the full range of host morphologies, and thus place these hosts in the context of ULIRGs and QSOs with prior CO detections. Specifically, we will (a) determine if optically-luminous QSOs, as a class, reside in gas-rich hosts (b) measure their star formation efficiencies and gas depletion times, (c) estimate their gas fraction and (d) determine if their gas is spatially compact, as observed in ULIRGs.
